body: Looking into this a little more I see a lot of test are failing at `Running org.apache.fluo.integration.client.FluoAdminImplIT` so I am going to look into that test

Do you have any specific area that interest you?  (e.g. Java, Maven, scripting, Web, concurrent code, algorithms, etc.)

That sounds great , I'm Okay with both. I will give my info here , 
_Name:_  Amal Krishnan

And my twitter username is [@amal_krish](https://twitter.com/amal_krish)

Thanks !

So, I'm not a fan of skipping ITs in Travis CI for a few reasons:

1. It means less testing,
2. It encourages more ITs over UTs when a faster UT would be appropriate, simply because we aren't as aware of the running cost ITs have as we would be if they ran all the time, and
3. It's most likely indicative of a bad test.

I think we should try to find a way to make the ITs work in Travis.

As for skipping the `accumulo-maven-plugin`, it's probably best to tie that to `-DskipITs`, rather than `-DskipTests` anyway. Also, could just use the built-in `-Daccumulo.skip` property.

I am not a fan of SkippingITs either as long as we can get the to run reliably.  I will make an attempt to get them to run reliably.  However, if ITs are causing the travis build to regularly fail then it makes automated PR testing useless.

We could skip them for now.  Personally, I think having builds that run reliably is better than having builds that run sometimes and test more.
Further, if a transaction fails to get a lock and then rolls back an existing lock then it can re-attempt getting its lock.

@jeremy

I have vacated this issue but others have shown interest. Please file a
pull request with WIP to let everyone know your have claimed and are
working on this issue. I hope I have phrased this correctly.

In my personal opinion, I think you can just start. You can always put a link to your personal branch, so others can collaborate with you on what will eventually be just a single pull request to the upstream Apache Fluo repository. Git being a distributed version control system is nice that way.
As long as you've made a good faith effort to collaborate (including accepting feedback), nobody can fault you for "sniping" a particular bug, in my opinion.

@jkosh44  there is a javadoc error, you can see this in the Travis build.  Javadoc is only built on demand.  Travis is configured to build it.  You can build it locally with the following commands.

```bash
mvn clean package javadoc:aggregate
# if builds, then following command can display it
firefox target/site/apidocs/index.html
```
@kpm1985 sorry I have not been able to look at your latest changes sooner.  I plan on looking at them tomorrow afternoon.
I restarted the travis build and it passed, so I merged it.   Thanks again @jkosh44

Yeap.  Let me know if you have any questions of feel free to post a WIP PR for discussion.

My thinking with the `copyTo()` method is that it avoid having to materialize the Keys when copying from `keys` to `keysFiltered`.  I proposed this after looking at the code and seeing that the filtering was done on timestamp only.  This works nicely with internal impl of ColumnBuffer that only keeps timestamps.

The travis build failed w/ following error

```
[ERROR] /home/travis/build/apache/fluo/modules/core/src/main/java/org/apache/fluo/core/impl/TransactorCache.java:[52,39] cannot find symbol
```
I've traced all occurrences of that constant, just learned eclipse has a nice select and then ctrl+h to search variables down. Way better than grep :)
Build failed this time based on timeout, did the same thing on my laptop before I pushed.

Speaking of eclipse tricks, the following may be a quick way to automatically replace the constant.

 * Set the old constant equals to the new constant, so  `CACHE_TIMEOUT_MIN = FluoConfigurationImpl.TX_INFO_CACHE_TIMEOUT_DEFAULT`
 * Highlight the old constant and then ask eclipse to inline it.  This should replace the old constant with the new everywhere. However, in this case still need to change the timeunit so not sure it really saves any time.
I was able to build this locally.  I squashed and merged in d9fc391ee1c761c83ba52cfca5358aee0b7329fa.  Thanks again @kpm1985  for the contribution.
Actually it does an entire row and all of it cols at once.  Could still do all row cols at once.
Also need to consider read locks if and when #917 is merged.

Thanks for the tip, pretty cool idea actually.

@kpm1985 looks good, I squashed and pushed commit 9e87f47

I think this task would consist of the following :
  * Add `FLUO_TMP` to [fluo-env.sh](https://github.com/apache/fluo/blob/9e87f477463602533d8611c9561484d41d135654/modules/distribution/src/main/config/fluo-env.sh)
  * Modify the [fluo script](https://github.com/apache/fluo/blob/9e87f477463602533d8611c9561484d41d135654/modules/distribution/src/main/scripts/fluo) to use `mktemp` and `FLUO_TMP` everywhere `FluoGetJars` is run.

For example the code [fluo line 230](https://github.com/apache/fluo/blob/9e87f477463602533d8611c9561484d41d135654/modules/distribution/src/main/scripts/fluo#L230) could be changed to the following :

```bash
    # create a temp dir to fetch application jars to
    app_lib=`mktemp -d "$FLUO_TMP"/fluo-"$app"-XXXXXXXXX`
    $JAVA org.apache.fluo.command.FluoGetJars -d "$app_lib" -a "$app"
    export CLASSPATH="$conf:$app_lib/*:$CLASSPATH"
    $JAVA org.apache.fluo.command.FluoExec "${@:2}"
    # remove the temp app lib dir
   rm -rf $app_lib
```
I posted this on helpwanted : https://helpwanted.apache.org/task.html?593d4c92b8bb1883de0ae0403646737a88d188a3

Great @mptap, let us know if you have any questions.   

@ctubbsii the trap command is neat, I didn't know about that.  I have never done signal handling bash.  I googled it, seems one may be able to use human readable signal codes like `ERR` and `INT` instead of numbers. I got a little lost w/ all the quoting in the trap command, I suspect its expanding the variable and still leaving it quoted after expanding.

I think using the trap command to schedule the deletion on process exit is the way to go.  I tried to redo my example from above using trap, not sure if its correct.

```bash
    app_lib=$(mktemp -d "$FLUO_TMP"/fluo-"$app"-XXXXXXXXX) || die "fatal: unable to allocate a temporary directory"
    # sechedule removal of app_lib tmp dir when this script exits
    trap "rm -rf '""$app_lib""'" 0 HUP INT QUIT TERM
    $JAVA org.apache.fluo.command.FluoGetJars -d "$app_lib" -a "$app"
    export CLASSPATH="$conf:$app_lib/*:$CLASSPATH"
    $JAVA org.apache.fluo.command.FluoExec "${@:2}"
```
@jkosh44 the static KeyValue class in GarbageCollectionIterator still needs to be removed, I had forgot about that when approving.

signal 0 should also be `EXIT`

I think you can actually simplify the trap command's quoting a bit, but if you do, it will generate a warning in shellcheck, for being a common mistake (I don't recommend this, but it may help understand what's being quoted and why):
```bash
trap "rm -rf '$app_lib'" EXIT HUP INT QUIT TERM
```

Nice!!

On Oct 25, 2017 2:43 PM, "Keith Turner" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> In the travisCI docs I found that its possible to use docker to run
> travis builds locally
> <https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/common-build-problems/#Troubleshooting-Locally-in-a-Docker-Image>
> (very cool!). I did this and got the FluoAdminIT test to hang. I found the
> problem was that a weird accumulo classpath context was being set. This
> caused tablets to fail to load sometimes (it was timing issue, seemed more
> likely in docker env). When the tablet failed to load the test would hang
> forever trying to delete the table in cleanup.
